population_projections.csv.name: Sub-Provincial Population Projections - P.E.O.P.L.E. 2016
population_projections.csv.description: A population projection is a forecast of future population growth. BC Stats applies the Component/Cohort-Survival method to project the population. This method "grows" the population from the latest base year estimate by forecasting births, deaths and migration by age. These forecasts are based on past trends modified to account for possible future changes and, consequently, should be viewed as only one possible scenario of future population. B.C. level projections are usually updated in May each year, with sub-provincial projections following a few months after. All population estimates and projections are as of July 1st.
population_projections.csv.data-notes: Click on the "BC Level Population Projection Technical Assumptions" link on this page:http://www.bcstats.gov.bc.ca/StatisticsBySubject/Demography/PopulationProjections.aspx

ptt_municipal_0616.csv.name: Property Transfer Tax (June 2016)
ptt_municipal_0616.csv.source: BC Ministy of Finance - Property Taxation
ptt_municipal_0616.csv.description: Property transfer tax data relating to market transactions within the province.
ptt_municipal_0616.csv.data-transformations: Data was mapped against the Canadian Census Sub-divisions. It only includes Municipal Monthly data.

ptt_municipal_months_aggregated.csv.description: Property transfer tax data relating to market transactions within the province.
ptt_municipal_months_aggregated.csv.data-transformations: Data was mapped against the Canadian Census Sub-divisions. It only includes Municipal Monthly data. All months were aggregated to form one value per municipality.
ptt_municipal_months_aggregated.csv.data-notes: For all notes and considerations for the data visit:https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca/dataset/property-transfer-tax-data

transitcosts_municipalities.csv.name: Cost of Public Transit by Municipality 2017
transitcosts_municipalities.csv.source-url: http://www.translink.ca/en/Fares-and-Passes/Single-Fares.aspx (Single fares);http://www.translink.ca/en/Fares-and-Passes/Monthly-Pass.aspx (Monthly pass); BC Transit (Victoria fares): https://bctransit.com/victoria/fares Replace "victoria" in the url with other “Coverage Area” names in the dataset, to access appropriate fares pages., Number of people using public transit
transitcosts_municipalities.csv.description: Cost of public transportation by BC Transit and Translink. Number of people who used public transportation to go to work (from NHS 2011)https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/prof/details/download-telecharger/comprehensive/comp-csv-tab-nhs-enm.cfm?Lang=E
transitcosts_municipalities.csv.data-transformations: Dataset was build by Plot + Scatter. Only municipalities with a positive number of people who take public transit have been included. Some rural areas have also been removed even if several people take transit.
transitcosts_municipalities.csv.data-notes: For all notes and considerations for the data visit:https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/ref/dict/pop153-eng.cfm

health-hospital-locations.csv.name: Hospital Locations
health-hospital-locations.csv.source: Ministry of Health - Provincial Health Services Authority
health-hospital-locations.csv.description: This layer currently includes BC Health Authority owned or operated hospitals with Emergency Departments and Acute Care beds. Affiliate facilities where Health Authorities fund beds will also be included.
health-hospital-locations.csv.data-notes: See notes and considerations for the data here:https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca/dataset/bc-health-care-facilities-hospital

health-clinic-locations.csv.name: Walk-In Clinic Locations
health-clinic-locations.csv.description: Programs in BC that provide walk-in treatment services for people who have minor illnesses or injuries that do not require a visit to a hospital emergency department or an urgent care facility. These programs are generally specialized practices set up by groups of physicians operating within the provincial-territorial heath system who are available for patients that do not have family physicians or who need medical treatment and-or diagnosis at times when their family physician is not available. In some areas, a walk-in clinic may rotate between the clinics of different physicians. Some programs, mainly in major metropolitan areas, may operate on a 24-hour basis but all tend to be open for some or all evenings and weekends. Definition is protected by Copyright by Information and Referral Federal of Los Angeles County, Inc (https://211taxonomy.org/subscriptions/#agreement)
health-clinic-locations.csv.data-notes: See notes and considerations for the data here: https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca/dataset/walk-in-clinics-in-bc

health-emergency-room-locations.csv.name: Emergency Room Locations
health-emergency-room-locations.csv.description: The primary purpose of this data is for populating the HealthLinkBC Directory. The HealthLinkBC Directory is a public service that provides detailed information about how and where to access health services in British Columbia...
health-emergency-room-locations.csv.data-transformations: Unused columns(STREET_NUMBER, STREET_TYPE, STREET_DIRECTION) were removed from the dataset in this  app.
health-emergency-room-locations.csv.data-notes: For all other notes and considerations about the data go here: https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca/dataset/emergency-rooms-in-bc

education-school-locations.csv.data-notes: For all other notes and considerations about the data go here: https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca/dataset/bc-schools-school-locations

bike_routes_kelowna.json.name: Bike Lanes Kelowna
bike_routes_kelowna.json.description: This data was pulled from the Active Transportation layer, the combination of both the Pedestrian and Bicycle Networks. The Pedestrian Network includes the following facility types: Shared-Use Pathway, Paved; Shared-Use Pathway, Unpaved; and Sidewalk. The Bicycle Network includes the following facility types: Cycle Track; Shared-Use Pathway, Paved; Shared-Use Pathway, Unpaved; and Bike Lane. Dataset updated continuously.
bike_routes_kelowna.json.data-transformations: Shape files were transformed into geojson files.
bike_routes_kelowna.json.data-notes: See notes and considerations for the data here:http://opendata.kelowna.ca/datasets/active-transportation

bike_routes_vancouver.json.name: Bike Lanes Vancouver
bike_routes_vancouver.json.source: Engineering Services - City of Vancouver Open Data Catalogue
bike_routes_vancouver.json.date: This data is updated frequently in the normal course of business, however priorities and resources determine how fast a change in reality is reflected in the database.  The extract on this website is updated weekly.
bike_routes_vancouver.json.description: Bikeways data: This data set contains the City’s dedicated bikeways.
bike_routes_vancouver.json.data-transformations: Shape files were transformed into geojson files.
bike_routes_vancouver.json.data-notes: See notes and considerations for the data here:http://data.vancouver.ca/datacatalogue/bikeways.htm

parks_kelowna.json.name: Parks Kelowna
parks_kelowna.json.description: Parks dataset includes developed, undeveloped, and future parks. The dataset also includes address and dog status. Dataset updated continuously.
parks_kelowna.json.data-transformations: Shape files were transformed into geojson files.
parks_kelowna.json.data-notes: See notes and considerations for the data here:http://opendata.kelowna.ca/datasets/park

parks_vancouver.json.name: Parks Vancouver
parks_vancouver.json.source: Board of Parks and Recreation - City of Vancouver Open Data Catalogue
parks_vancouver.json.date: Data taken from Park Board site in July 2009. The data on this site is updated weekly.
parks_vancouver.json.description: This data set provides information on the names and locations of City parks and is displayed in polygon features (a polygon or area coloured green to show the extent of the park boundaries).
parks_vancouver.json.data-transformations: Shape files were transformed into geojson files.
parks_vancouver.json.data-notes: The data may also be displayed as point features (a single point representing the location of the park; this is unlikely to be the geometric centroid of the park). See notes and considerations for the data here: http://data.vancouver.ca/datacatalogue/parks.htm
